p: Money was raised rapidly from the international communi ty for HIV and AIDS. In 2001, Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations, called for spending on HIV/AIDS to be increased tenfold in developing countries, and the Global Fund for AIDS, TB and Malaria (GFATM) was established. In 2003, President George W. Bush pledged US$15 billion toward the Presidential Emergency Program for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), and WHO launched the “3 × 5” campaign to have three million people on treatment by 2005 (Whiteside and Lee 2005). The problem is that the existence of external resources means in many countries the bulk of epidemic funding comes from international sources, therefore creating an unhealthy situation of dependency.
